unnormalised: IIT Delhi's cut-off for CSE touched 98.5 percentile in the first round of JEE Advanced counselling, revealed officials on 20/06/2024. This is slightly higher than last year’s 98.2 percentile. Many students are now waiting anxiously for the 2nd list, hoping to get a seat in their preferred branch.
normalised: I-I-T Delhi's cut-off for C-S-E touched ninety eight point five percentile in the first round of J-E-E Advanced counselling, revealed officials on twentieth June two thousand and twenty four. This is slightly higher than last year’s ninety eight point two percentile. Many students are now waiting anxiously for the second list, hoping to get a seat in their preferred branch.

unnormalised: Meanwhile, Delhi University (DU) is seeing a rush for B.Com (Hons) with over 50,000 applications received by 15/07/2024, said Registrar Vikas Gupta. Lady Shri Ram College (LSR) and Hindu College remain popular choices. The first cut-off list for DU is expected around 25th July, and experts are predicting it could be as high as 99% for some courses in these colleges. Students are advised to keep checking the website du.ac.in for updates.
normalised: Meanwhile, Delhi University (D-U) is seeing a rush for B.Com (Hons) with over fifty thousand applications received by fifteenth July two thousand and twenty four, said Registrar Vikas Gupta. Lady Shri Ram College (L-S-R) and Hindu College remain popular choices. The first cut-off list for D-U is expected around twenty fifth July, and experts are predicting it could be as high as ninety nine percent for some courses in these colleges. Students are advised to keep checking the website d-u.a-c.i-n for updates.

unnormalised: Speaking of updates, the AICTE has announced that engineering colleges can now admit students based on their 12th marks if seats remain vacant after JEE counselling. This is to ensure no seats go to waste and to give a chance to students who might've missed the JEE. Further details are available at aicte-india.org.
normalised: Speaking of updates, the A-I-C-T-E has announced that engineering colleges can now admit students based on their twelfth marks if seats remain vacant after J-E-E counselling. This is to ensure no seats go to waste and to give a chance to students who might've missed the J-E-E. Further details are available at a-i-c-t-e-india.o-r-g.
